meaning: An advanced branch of mathematics that deals mostly with rates of change and with finding lengths, areas, and volumes.
A rule or correspondence which associates to each number x in a set A a unique number f(x) in a set B.
A drawing that uses a series of dots, lines, etc., to show how much or how quickly something changes.
The set of all possible inputs for the function.
The complete set of all possible resulting values of the dependent variable.
A quantity that can have any one of a set of values or a symbol that represents such a quantity.
An upward or downward slant.
The point where the line or curve crosses the axis of the graph.
One which is defined not by a single equation, but by two or more.
The non-negative value of x without regard to its sign.
A piecewise constant function having only finitely many pieces.
Functions which satisfy particular symmetry relations, with respect to taking additive inverses.
The quality of something that has two sides or halves that are the same or very close in size, shape, and position.
If f'(x) > 0 at each point in an interval I, then the function is said to be increasing on I. If f'(x) < 0 at each point in an interval I, then the function is said to be decreasing on I.
A function whose graph is a straight line, that is, a polynomial function of degree zero or one.
A function that involves only non-negative integer powers or only positive integer exponents of a variable in an equation like the quadratic equation, cubic equation, etc.
Polynomial functions with one or more variables in which the highest power of the variable is two.
A function of the form where a is nonzero; or in other words, a function defined by a polynomial of degree three.
A function where y = x^n where n is any real constant number.
Any number that is not a fraction or decimal: any whole number or its negative.
